unit_learning_outcomes.description: Interface a CPU with both internal and external functional units.
Distinguish between the different external and internal interfaces and select which is most appropriate for a given circumstance.
Program an embedded system in both the assembly and C languages.
Construct state machines on an embedded system
Describe the various components that comprise a modern embedded system, including those that are essential and those that are optional.

enrolment_rules.description: (130cp at 1000 level or above including ELEC2042 or ELEC242 or ELEC241 or MTRN2060 or ELEC260)

assessments.description: This is a public demonstration of the major project. Each student will present their work and answer questions about the deign, implementation and functioning of their system.
This Quiz will be a reprise of the information learnt in the unit so far.
The diagnostic Quiz is a reference point that covers the pre-requisites for the unit and gives an indication whether you have the required pre-requisite knowledge.

In this defence the student must describe the final design and justify why it will solve the requirements of the major project. The design at this stage must include the final state machine, as well as the programming constructs that will implement this state machine.

During the first weeks various background problems are to be investigated and solutions coded. These tasks will introduce the development system, and also cover some fundamental peripheral units that will be needed for the major project.

The minor project allows the student to present a project that they have been working on. It is used to provide experience for the major project, and is an important milestone to achieving the learning outcomes.

This is the first of the two defences for the unit. In this defence the student will defend their preliminary design. The design at this stage must include the state machine and the peripheral units that will be utilised to accomplish the major project

data.description: Project-based unit. Students complete a major project that emphasize aspects of digital computing systems, including state machines, digital data processing, arithmetic processing, timing, internal and external peripherals. Students will design a program for a microcontroller that will perform processing of real world data to achieve a defined aim. This programming exercise will be used to explore the complexities that make up digital hardware designs.
